title: Introduction to neuroUp
text: example, read Feedback task fMRI region interest data using read_csv() function readr package. data comes shipped NeuroUp package two forms: R dataset can directly call using feedback csv file extdata/ folder. , load data csv-file mimic expected use-case region interest data similar format: csv-file locally can load directly like :
code: # load feedback.csv data located at local system  feedback_csv <- (system.file("extdata/feedback.csv", package = "neuroUp"))  # use read_csv function to load csv-file as tibble feedback_data <- readr::read_csv(feedback_csv) #> Rows: 271 Columns: 4 #> ── Column specification ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Delimiter: "," #> dbl (4): participant_id, age, mfg_learning, mfg_application #>  #> ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data. #> ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message. taskname_data <- readr::read_csv("path/to/filename.csv")

what: Estimate raw differences and Cohen’s d
title: Introduction to neuroUp
text: estim_diff allows determine sample size required estimate differences raw means Cohen’s d’s multiple sample sizes certain precision. Precision presented form 95% highest density credible interval (HDCI), , narrowest possible interval believed contain true value parameter interest probability .95 . narrower interval, higher precision parameter estimated. example, interested contrast learning phase application phase atlas-based middle frontal gyrus feedback task. use existing dataset sample size N = 271, sample sizes minimum (e.g., N = 20) maximum sample size sample hand estim_diff() function compute HDCI. account arbitrary order participant data set, done set number permutations (50 default), participants data set. sample size, average HDCI permutations also calculated. following arguments need provided: data dataframe data analyzed (feedback_data example) vars_of_interest vector containing names variables compared means (c("mfg_learning", "mfg_application") example) sample_size range sample size used (20:271 example) k number permutations used sample size. use smaller number (20) default (50) reduce build-time vignette name optional title dataset variables displayed figures. use "Feedback middle frontal gyrus" example provide arguments estim_diff() function store new object called feedback_estim. , set seed value make sure get results re-running function.
code: set.seed(1234)  feedback_estim <- estim_diff(feedback_data,                              c("mfg_learning", "mfg_application"), 20:271,                              20, "Feedback middle frontal gyrus")

text: estim_diff() function provides several outputs can call explore results estimations. display different outputs .

what: fig_diff: scatterplot with HDCI’s for difference in raw means
title: Introduction to neuroUp
text: First, plot fig_diff, returns scatterplot difference raw means, five different sample sizes, 10 total number HDCI’s computed displayed (light blue). average estimate credible interval summarizing total number HDCIs sample size plotted reddish purple

text: final plot display fig_d_nozero, returns barplot five sample sizes proportion permutations containing zero displayed Cohen’s d:

previous_headings: Estimate raw differences and Cohen’s d > Explore estim_diff() output
title: Introduction to neuroUp
text: estim_diff() function also returns two tibbles values previous plots based. tbl_select returns tibble containing estimates difference raw means Cohen’s d associated SD, SE, 95% CI, width 95% CI (lower, upper) five different sample sizes (starting minimum sample size, 1/5th parts total dataset). summary data used plot figures: tbl_total returns tibble containing estimates difference raw means Cohen’s d associated SD, SE, 95% CI, width 95% CI (lower, upper) sample sizes, including permutation number. total (large) table estimates requested sample sizes permutations:

title: Introduction to neuroUp
text: example, read Gambling task fMRI region interest data using read_csv() function readr package. Just like Feedback data , data comes shipped NeuroUp package two forms: R dataset can directly call using gambling csv file extdata/ folder. , load data csv-file mimic expected use-case region interest data similar format:
code: # load gambling.csv data located at local system  gambling_csv <- (system.file("extdata/gambling.csv", package = "neuroUp"))  # use read_csv function to load csv-file as tibble gambling_data <- readr::read_csv(gambling_csv) #> Rows: 221 Columns: 5 #> ── Column specification ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Delimiter: "," #> dbl (5): participant_id, age, lnacc_self_win, lnacc_self_loss, lnacc_self_wi... #>  #> ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data. #> ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

title: Introduction to neuroUp
text: estim_corr allows determine sample size required estimate Pearson correlations multiple sample sizes certain precision. Precision presented form 95% highest density credible interval (HDCI), , narrowest possible interval believed contain true value parameter interest probability .95 . narrower interval, higher precision parameter estimated. example, interested correlation age activity anatomical mask left nucleus accumbens gambling task (winning self > losing self contrast). use existing dataset sample size N = 221, sample sizes minimum (e.g., N = 20) maximum sample size sample hand estim_corr() function compute HDCI. account arbitrary order participant data set, done set number permutations (50 default), participants data set. sample size, average HDCI permutations also calculated. following arguments need provided: data dataframe data analyzed (gambling_data example) vars_of_interest vector containing names variables correlated (c("lnacc_self_winvsloss", "age") example) sample_size range sample size used (20:221 example) k number permutations used sample size. use smaller number (20) default (50) reduce build-time vignette name optional title dataset variables displayed figures. use "Gambling NAcc correlation w/ age" example provide arguments estim_corr() function store new object called gambling_estim. , set seed value make sure get results re-running function.
code: set.seed(1234)  gambling_estim <- estim_corr(gambling_data,                              c("lnacc_self_winvsloss", "age"), 20:221,                              20, "Gambling NAcc correlation w/ age")

title: Introduction to neuroUp
text: estim_corr() function provides several outputs can call explore results estimations. display different outputs .

what: fig_corr: scatterplot with HDCI’s for correlations
title: Introduction to neuroUp
text: First, plot fig_corr, returns scatterplot difference raw means, five different sample sizes, 10 total number HDCI’s computed displayed (green). average estimate credible interval summarizing total number HDCIs sample size plotted orange:

what: fig_nozero: barplot with proportion permutations not containing zero for the correlations
title: Introduction to neuroUp
text: second plot display fig_corr_nozero, returns barplot five sample sizes proportion permutations containing zero displayed correlations:

what: tbl_select & tbl_total: tibbles with estimates of the correlations
title: Introduction to neuroUp
text: estim_corr() function also returns two tibbles values previous plots based. tbl_select returns tibble containing estimates Pearson’s correlation two correlated variables associated SD, SE, 95% CI, width 95% CI (lower, upper) five different sample sizes (starting minimum sample size, 1/5th parts total dataset). summary data used plot figures: tbl_total returns tibble containing estimates Pearson’s correlation two correlated variables associated SD, SE, 95% CI, width 95% CI (lower, upper) sample sizes, including permutation number. total (large) table estimates requested sample sizes permutations:

title: Authors and Citation
text: Klapwijk E, Hoijtink H, Jongerling J (2024). “neuroUp: Plan sample size fMRI regions interest research using Bayesian updating.” doi:10.5281/zenodo.11526169.
code: @Misc{,   title = {neuroUp: Plan sample size for fMRI regions of                    interest research using Bayesian updating},   author = {Eduard Klapwijk and Herbert Hoijtink and Joran Jongerling},   year = {2024},   doi = {10.5281/zenodo.11526169}, }

title: Plan Sample Size for Task fMRI Research using Bayesian Updating
text: goal neuroUp perform empirical sample size determination Bayesian updating region interest based task-related fMRI studies. elaborate introduction method, see paper: Klapwijk, E. T., Jongerling, J., Hoijtink, H., & Crone, E. . (2025). Sample size estimation task-related functional MRI studies using Bayesian updating. Developmental Cognitive Neuroscience, 71, 101489. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.dcn.2024.101489

title: Plan Sample Size for Task fMRI Research using Bayesian Updating
text: Run following R: can install latest development version neuroUp GitHub : run following get started:

title: Estimate correlations — estim_corr
text: estim_corr determines point estimate, SD SE, 95% Credibility Intervals, interval width, Pearson correlations multiple sample sizes

title: Estimate correlations — estim_corr
text: data Dataframe data analyzed vars_of_interest Vector containing names variables correlated: c("var1", "var2") sample_size range sample size used: min:max k number permutations used sample size. Defaults 50 name title dataset variables displayed figure. Defaults ""

title: Estimate correlations — estim_corr
text: tbl_select returns tibble::tibble() containing estimates Pearson correlation two correlated variables associated SD, SE, 95% CI, width 95% CI (lower, upper) five different sample sizes (starting minimum sample size, 1/5th parts total dataset). fig_corr returns scatterplot five different sample sizes, 10 total number HDCIs computed displayed (green). average estimate credible interval summarizing total number HDCIs sample size plotted orange fig_corr_nozero returns barplot five sample sizes proportion permutations containing zero displayed tbl_total returns tibble::tibble() containing estimates Pearson correlation two correlated variables associated SD, SE, 95% CI, width 95% CI (lower, upper) sample sizes, including permutation number.

title: Estimate differences (unstandardized and Cohen's d) — estim_diff
text: tbl_select returns tibble::tibble() containing estimates difference raw means Cohen's d associated SD, SE, 95% CI, width 95% CI (lower, upper) five different sample sizes (starting minimum sample size, 1/5th parts total dataset). fig_diff returns scatterplot difference raw means, five different sample sizes, 10 total number HDCI's computed displayed (light blue). average estimate credible interval summarizing total number HDCIs sample size plotted reddish purple fig_nozero returns barplot five sample sizes proportion permutations containing zero displayed difference raw means fig_cohens_d returns scatterplot Cohen's d, five different sample sizes, 10 total number HDCI's computed displayed (light blue). average estimate credible interval summarizing total number HDCIs sample size plotted reddish purple fig_d_nozero returns barplot five sample sizes proportion permutations containing zero displayed Cohen's d tbl_total returns tibble::tibble() containing estimates difference raw means Cohen's d associated SD, SE, 95% CI, width 95% CI (lower, upper) sample sizes, including permutation number.

what: Feedback task fMRI region of interest data — feedback
title: Feedback task fMRI region of interest data — feedback
text: dataset containing parameter estimates atlas-based middle frontal gyrus (Harvard-Oxford cortical atlas; thresholded 50%; center--mass coordinates x = -4, y = 22, z = 43), ), one value mean activation learning one value mean activation application participants.

title: Feedback task fMRI region of interest data — feedback
Feedback task fMRI region of interest data — feedback
text: data frame 271 rows 4 variables: participant_id unique id every participant age age years (8.01-25.95) mfg_learning parameter estimates middle frontal gyrus learning phase (-2.54-4.83) mfg_application parameter estimates middle frontal gyrus application phase (-6.46-3.09)

title: Feedback task fMRI region of interest data — feedback
text: Peters, S., & Crone, E. . (2017). Increased striatal activity adolescence benefits learning. Nature Communications, 8(1), 1983. doi:10.1038/s41467-017-02174-z

what: Gambling task fMRI region of interest data — gambling
title: Gambling task fMRI region of interest data — gambling
text: dataset containing parameter estimates anatomical mask left nucleus accumbens (Harvard-Oxford subcortical atlas; thresholded 40%; 28 voxels included), one value mean activation winning one value mean activation losing participants.

title: Gambling task fMRI region of interest data — gambling
Gambling task fMRI region of interest data — gambling
text: data frame 221 rows 5 variables: participant_id unique id every participant age age years (11.94-28.46) lnacc_self_win parameter estimates left nucleas accumbens winning (-2.78-3.41) lnacc_self_loss parameter estimates left nucleas accumbens losing (-3.84-3.28) lnacc_self_winvsloss parameter estimates left nucleas accumbens contrast winning versus losing (-2.60-4.47)

title: Gambling task fMRI region of interest data — gambling

title: neuroUp 0.3.1
text: CRAN release: 2024-08-28

title: neuroUp 0.3.0
text: Preprint published added readme (https://doi.org/10.31234/osf.io/cz32t) Adapted description documentation comply CRAN policy

title: neuroUp 0.2.0
text: Confidence intervals Cohen’s d now calculated using bootstrapping (100 times per permutation) Permutation number used averages now increased (999999) avoid misplotting testing 999 permutations Logo created added

title: neuroUp 0.1.1
text: Calculation standard error Cohen’s d corrected Data added .rda .csv format, documentation added
